translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
The Questions of the Youth Upasīva
“Alone, I am, O Sakka, a great mass of darkness,
(So said the venerable Upasīva)
Unanchored, I am not able to cross over.
Tell me a support, O All-Seeing One,
Anchored on which I might cross over this flood.”
“Looking at nothingness, mindful,
(The Blessed One said to Upasīva)
Depending on ‘it is not’, cross over the flood.
Having given up sense pleasures, abstaining from talk,
See the ending of craving as the great gain.”
“Whoever is free from passion for all sense pleasures,
(So said the venerable Upasīva)
Anchored on nothingness, having given up conceit;
Freed in the supreme freedom of perception-&-form,
Would he stand there without clinging?”
“Whoever is free from passion for all sense pleasures,
(The Blessed One said to Upasīva)
Anchored on nothingness, having given up conceit;
Freed in the supreme freedom of perception-&-form,
He would stand there without clinging.”
“If he would stand there without clinging,
Even for a hundred years, O All-Seeing One,

analyzed: tattha iva saḥ sīti siyā vimutto
translated: Right there he is cooled and liberated,
So direct your consciousness to one such as him.”
“Just as a flame blown out by the wind
(Upasīva said:)
goes out and does not continue,
So the sage liberated from the body
goes out and does not continue.”

analyzed: atthaṅgataḥ saḥ uda vā so natthi
translated: “Has he gone to an end or not gone to an end,
or is he perhaps healthy and living still?
Please explain this to me, O sage,

original: Tathā hi te vidito esa dhammo”.
analyzed: tathā hi te viditaḥ esa dhammo
translated: for you know this Dhamma well.”
“There is no measure for one who has gone to an end,
(Upasīva said:)

original: Yena naṁ vajjuṁ taṁ tassa natthi;
analyzed: yena nam vajjum tam tassa natthi
translated: there is nothing by which he could be described.
When all things have been completely abandoned,
all verbal expressions have been completely abandoned.”
The Discussion with the Youth Upasīva is finished.
